#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Chapter
#Text=1
#Text=“ Are we rising again ? ”
#Text=“ No.
#Text=On the contrary . ”
#Text=“ Are we descending ? ”
#Text=“ Worse than that , captain !
#Text=we are falling ! ”
#Text=“ For Heaven ’s sake heave out the ballast ! ”
#Text=“ There ! the last sack is empty ! ”
#Text=“ Does the balloon rise ? ”
#Text=“ No ! ”
#Text=“ I hear a noise like the dashing of waves .
#Text=The sea is below the car !
#Text=It cannot be more than 500 feet from us ! ”
#Text=“ Overboard with every weight ! ... everything ! ”
#Text=Such were the loud and startling words which resounded through the air , above the vast watery desert of the Pacific , about four o’clock in the evening of the 23rd of March , 1865 .
#Text=Few can possibly have forgotten the terrible storm from the northeast , in the middle of the equinox of that year .
#Text=The tempest raged without intermission from the 18th to the 26th of March .

#Text=Its ravages were terrible in America , Europe , and Asia , covering a distance of eighteen hundred miles , and extending obliquely to the equator from the thirty-fifth north parallel to the fortieth south parallel .

#Text=Towns were overthrown , forests uprooted , coasts devastated by the mountains of water which were precipitated on them , vessels cast on the shore , which the published accounts numbered by hundreds , whole districts leveled by waterspouts which destroyed everything they passed over , several thousand people crushed on land or drowned at sea ; such were the traces of its fury , left by this devastating tempest .
#Text=It surpassed in disasters those which so frightfully ravaged Havana and Guadalupe , one on the 25th of October , 1810 , the other on the 26th of July , 1825 .
#Text=But while so many catastrophes were taking place on land and at sea , a drama not less exciting was being enacted in the agitated air .

#Text=In fact , a balloon , as a ball might be carried on the summit of a waterspout , had been taken into the circling movement of a column of air and had traversed space at the rate of ninety miles an hour , turning round and round as if seized by some aerial maelstrom .
#Text=Beneath the lower point of the balloon swung a car , containing five passengers , scarcely visible in the midst of the thick vapor mingled with spray which hung over the surface of the ocean .
#Text=Whence , it may be asked , had come that plaything of the tempest ?
#Text=From what part of the world did it rise ?
#Text=It surely could not have started during the storm .
#Text=But the storm had raged five days already , and the first symptoms were manifested on the 18th .
#Text=It cannot be doubted that the balloon came from a great distance , for it could not have traveled less than two thousand miles in twenty-four hours .
#Text=At any rate the passengers , destitute of all marks for their guidance , could not have possessed the means of reckoning the route traversed since their departure .
#Text=It was a remarkable fact that , although in the very midst of the furious tempest , they did not suffer from it .
#Text=They were thrown about and whirled round and round without feeling the rotation in the slightest degree , or being sensible that they were removed from a horizontal position .
#Text=Their eyes could not pierce through the thick mist which had gathered beneath the car .
#Text=Dark vapor was all around them .
#Text=Such was the density of the atmosphere that they could not be certain whether it was day or night .
#Text=No reflection of light , no sound from inhabited land , no roaring of the ocean could have reached them , through the obscurity , while suspended in those elevated zones .
#Text=Their rapid descent alone had informed them of the dangers which they ran from the waves .
#Text=However , the balloon , lightened of heavy articles , such as ammunition , arms , and provisions , had risen into the higher layers of the atmosphere , to a height of 4,500 feet .

#Text=The voyagers , after having discovered that the sea extended beneath them , and thinking the dangers above less dreadful than those below , did not hesitate to throw overboard even their most useful articles , while they endeavored to lose no more of that fluid , the life of their enterprise , which sustained them above the abyss .
#Text=The night passed in the midst of alarms which would have been death to less energetic souls .
#Text=Again the day appeared and with it the tempest began to moderate .
#Text=From the beginning of that day , the 24th of March , it showed symptoms of abating .
#Text=At dawn , some of the lighter clouds had risen into the more lofty regions of the air .
#Text=In a few hours the wind had changed from a hurricane to a fresh breeze , that is to say , the rate of the transit of the atmospheric layers was diminished by half .
#Text=It was still what sailors call “ a close-reefed topsail breeze , ” but the commotion in the elements had none the less considerably diminished .
#Text=Towards eleven o’clock , the lower region of the air was sensibly clearer .
#Text=The atmosphere threw off that chilly dampness which is felt after the passage of a great meteor .
#Text=The storm did not seem to have gone farther to the west .
#Text=It appeared to have exhausted itself .
#Text=Could it have passed away in electric sheets , as is sometimes the case with regard to the typhoons of the Indian Ocean ?
#Text=But at the same time , it was also evident that the balloon was again slowly descending with a regular movement .
#Text=It appeared as if it were , little by little , collapsing , and that its case was lengthening and extending , passing from a spherical to an oval form .
#Text=Towards midday the balloon was hovering above the sea at a height of only 2,000 feet .

#Text=It contained 50,000 cubic feet of gas , and , thanks to its capacity , it could maintain itself a long time in the air , although it should reach a great altitude or might be thrown into a horizontal position .
